title: Coroner judges that former British Judo champion Craig Fallon killed himself
text:
Craig Fallon, the former world judo champion, emailed his partner and said “remember, this was my choice” before being found dead in woodland earlier this year.

At an inquest on Wednesday in Shrewsbury, Shropshire coroner John Ellery recorded a conclusion of suicide and referenced mental health issues, including depression, which he said “sets the background as to what may have happened”.

Fallon, who was 36 when he died, was the last British judoka to win a world title - triumphing in the Under-60kg category at the World Championships in Cairo in 2005 - and is one of only two men alongside Neil Adams to hold both the world and European titles simultaneously.

He was described by Nigel Donohue, the performance director at British Judo, as the “outstanding judo fighter of his generation” and “the most talented judoka I have ever had the pleasure to watch competing for Great Britain”. He also won the 2002 Commonwealth title and competed in two Olympic Games.

A father of one, Fallon retired in 2011 and coached in Austria before becoming head coach earlier this year of the Welsh Judo Association.

It was reported at his inquest that the police were called at 6pm on July 14 after he had told his partner earlier in the day that she would never see him again. He left a last message that evening at 6.05pm as well as what was described as a “personal and private” email. A search began near the Wrekin in Shropshire and Fallon’s body was found the following morning. “Without going into detail, Craig was then found and he was deceased,” said Ellery.
description: Craig Fallon, the former world judo champion, emailed his partner and said “remember, this was my choice” before being found dead in woodland earlier this year.
